Imagine the kids who would be alive today if it weren't for Heller. 

Imagine elections without SuperPACs. 

Imagine having a full Voting Rights Act.
In practice, that means that we shouldn't do the work of propping up the Court. Make it legitimize itself, if it can, but don't buy into its own story of being a principled institution.
Concentrated elite unaccountable power usually ends in violence, and the rare moments that it doesn't should be treated as gifts, not expectations.

Judicial supremacy was always a dangerous and fragile bet, and I don't blame the Marshall Court, etc for using the power it had in serious and moral ways, but I do blame the left for putting serious trust in it as a keeper of our rights.

IMHO Roberts has worked hard to maintain this "criticize the case, respect the institution" model among lawyers--June 2013 when he rolled out Windsor 2 days after Shelby County, was  of those moments, where those criticizing the institutional legitimacy felt likely lonely wolves.
We treat it as an institution that on the whole enriches democratic power with occasional errors, instead of a strange, elite, unaccountable, undemocratic institution with rare power moral moments.
More seriously, lawyers and law professors do an enormous amount of work to prop up the legitimacy of the Supreme Court.
If the Court is looking to overturn precedents there's always Marbury.

presumption that an excess in price is 'unconscionably extreme'?"

Two years ago, the New York Legislature gave the New York Attorney General new rulemaking authority to effectuate our price gouging statute, GBL 396r, which bans, among other things "unconscionably extreme" price increases during a market disruption.

We have heard from retailers, people taking notice of prices they have paid for gas, food, and cable, academics, advocates for the elderly, and we want to hear from you!

16 Households in the bottom 20% of income pay on average 33.9% of their income  toward health care. A quarter of households spend at least 6% of their income on energy costs, and a tenth spend over 10%, so when energy costs spike, people frequently cannot pay their bills.

These and other price increases affected all New York households, with the heaviest burden  falling on those with low incomes. For instance, the poorest 20% of families spend around 27%  of their budgets on food, so a small increase in food prices lead to foregoing necessities.

During the pandemic from January 2021 to January 2022 "gasoline prices increased  39.6%; the cost of used vehicles increased 41.6%; the cost of new vehicles increased by 18.4%; the cost of meats, poultry, fish, and eggs increased 16%;  and household energy costs increased 21.4%."

6)What steps can be taken to increase transparency by disclosing companies‚Äô cost increases to consumers to help detect price gouging?

5)      What role does profit play in determining whether price gouging has occurred?  Should manufacturers and distributors of covered goods and services be permitted to increase their profit margins during a period of abnormal market disruptions through price increases?
4)Is there any reason that, in the presence of abnormal disruptions, it would not be feasible to limit price increases for covered goods and services to the amount of cost increases?
3)What industry characteristics are likely to facilitate and potentially mask price gouging?

1) One distinct feature of New York‚Äôs price gouging statute is that it applies to every party in the supply chain. What kinds of price gouging by wholesalers, manufacturers, suppliers and distributors is most likely to occur in a pandemic, and how would enforcers detect it?

Big companies are experiencing a 70-year high in corporate profit margins.

"The law also prohibits price gouging not just of consumers but also small businesses and state and local governments.

"While not all of these may be illegal, some of them may fit the definition of price gouging under New York law." 

NY law bans ‚Äúunconscionably excessive‚Äù prices, which include both ‚Äúunconscionably extreme‚Äù prices and prices set through ‚Äúunfair leverage or unconscionable means.‚Äù

(Sorry, I'm quoting the @NewYorkStateAG press release here, to be clear!)

"Shipping prices are way up, while shipping company profit margins are breaking records.

Chevron and Shell posted record profitability while energy costs soared."

Chipotle prices are up 10 percent from January 2021 to January 2022, which the company blames on labor shortages, but their operating income rose 181 percent.

While the cost of a basic cup of coffee at Starbucks has shot up 20 percent, the company profits are up 30 percent.

Beef prices rose 30 percent, while meatpackers have been celebrating an average of 120 percent increase in profits.

The cost of Proctor and Gamble diapers, toothpaste, detergent, and tampons has risen throughout the pandemic while P&G has boasted record-breaking profits.

Whether you are an industry expert, a retailer, a consumer, a patient, your comments matter. 

Comments should be submitted to stopillegalprofiteering@ag.ny.gov by April 15, 2022.
